stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on 'Course 11,' an industrial level featuring an oil rig. The primary focus was developing a scene where Bowser's minions are protesting. This involved creating dialogue with ChatGPT and team members, implementing animations, designing the interior of Bowser's office, and brainstorming a narrative-driven boss fight trigger. He also showcased and discussed N64 performance optimizations for the level.

development_findings.summary: Kaze used ChatGPT as a starting point to generate dialogue for protesting minions, then refined the ideas with his team to create character-specific puns.
development_findings.quote: This environment is crushing, and believe me, I know a thing or two about crushing.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a custom feature to squish the dialogue box for a flattened Goomba character, tweaking the effect to balance the visual gag with readability.
development_findings.quote: Hey, we get the flat text, all right, it works. I think it's too flat though, it's like unreadable.

development_findings.summary: Kaze designed a multi-stage, narrative-driven trigger for a boss fight, where the player overhears Bowser, finds the level has changed, and is then ambushed, creating a more dramatic encounter.
development_findings.quote: So you come out and then it starts. That's perfect. That is what I'll do.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has been actively optimizing the level for N64 hardware, achieving what he considers an acceptable framerate (25-29 FPS) in the most performance-intensive areas.
development_findings.quote: 25 for the worst part of the level, in a level like this, I'm fine with that.

development_findings.summary: To mask distracting model pop-in on the N64, Kaze created custom animations where enemies smoothly scale into view or emerge from the ground.
development_findings.quote: You see how he like smoothly scaled, and now when I come close, he comes back out of the ground.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided against adding hats to the Thwomp enemies, arguing it didn't fit their invulnerable nature and would interfere with the gameplay mechanic of climbing on them.
development_findings.quote: I am very much against them. I think it would just not work. Besides, then you couldn't plan for them anymore.

development_findings.summary: Multiplayer is a planned feature, but its implementation is dependent on finishing the quaternion animation system first. Kaze anticipates performance challenges, estimating it may run as low as 20 FPS.
development_findings.quote: I'm planning to add multiplayer after we have Quaternion animations. Unfortunately, I don't know how well it's going to run. I think the lowest it will run is like 20 FPS.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes replayability in his game should come from player skill improvement and discovering shortcuts, rather than unlockable content like a New Game+ mode.
context_findings.quote: You get better at Mario, you find new shortcuts that have replayability.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a design principle against including random internet memes in the game to maintain thematic consistency.
context_findings.quote: Do you think I am cringe? I think just adding random memes to your hacks is just cringe. Unless it's specifically a meme hack, you should not do it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering a future large-scale community project to create an Ocarina of Time ROM hack, structured to emulate a professional game studio's workflow.
context_findings.quote: I was thinking we should develop like an Ocarina of Time hack. But instead of developing it like normally, we'll do it like a professional game studio... And we'll do it properly with GitHub and a QA team and all those things.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering selling physical merchandise like game boxes and OST cartridges, but is aware of the potential legal issues with trademarks (like 'Yoshi') and licensed audio samples, planning to consult a lawyer.
context_findings.quote: I would definitely ask a lawyer beforehand. But that's in the future anyway.

biobak.summary: Biobak contributed several high-quality, pun-based dialogue lines for the protesting Koopas, which Kaze praised as being better than the AI-generated ones.
biobak.quote: I'm working day and night for him and he isn't even able to shell out a few coins for us.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided feedback on the oil texture, stating the colors were too intense and that he would work on a new version.
Biobak requested the 3D model for the 'oil block' enemy, stating he had an idea for it.

zeina.summary: Zeina is animating a complex Wiggler character and is working through the process segment by segment to manage the difficulty.
zeina.quote: I'm working on just trying to get a good walk cycle going on. So I'm doing it one segment at a time so it doesn't just fry my brain cells.

zeina.summary: Zeina identified a technical issue with the Wiggler's 3D model, where the root bone was placed in its chest, making it very difficult to animate correctly.
zeina.quote: Why is the root of Wiggler on his chest?

zeina.summary: Zeina created a set of animations for the Goomba character, including a sitting, falling, and protesting hop animation, which Kaze implemented in the game.

key_stories.title: Giving the Protest a Voice
key_stories.summary: To write dialogue for a protest scene, Kaze started with AI-generated ideas but found the best lines came from his teammate, Biobak. This collaborative process resulted in funnier, more fitting dialogue that elevated the scene.
key_stories.challenge: The protest scene needed dialogue to make it feel alive and convey the minions' humorous grievances against Bowser.
key_stories.process: Kaze first used ChatGPT to generate initial ideas. While some concepts were good, he found the execution lacking. Team member Biobak then contributed several superior lines, which Kaze immediately decided to use, praising his natural talent for writing them.
key_stories.outcome: The protest scene was populated with witty, pun-filled dialogue from multiple characters, enhancing the level's narrative and comedic tone. The process highlighted a successful collaboration between Kaze and Biobak, and a pragmatic use of AI for brainstorming.
key_stories.key_quote: Biobak's just naturally good at coming up with phrases.

key_stories.title: The Squished Goomba Gag
key_stories.summary: Kaze decided to make a flattened Goomba's dialogue box also appear squished. After some technical implementation, the gag was successfully added to the game, creating a unique visual joke and sparking a humorous real-life conversation with his wife, Zeina.
key_stories.challenge: A Goomba character gets flattened in the level, and Kaze wanted to extend the visual gag beyond the character model itself.
key_stories.process: Kaze conceived the idea to squish the dialogue box to match the flattened Goomba. He then worked through the technical implementation live on stream, adjusting a scaling matrix in the code. After getting it to work, he tweaked the values to ensure the text remained readable.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented code to make the Goomba's dialogue box appear squished, creating a unique and funny UI gag. The dialogue itself sparked a humorous, personal exchange between Kaze and his wife, Zeina, on stream.
key_stories.key_quote: Imagine the face of my wife when I slide under the front door tonight.

key_stories.title: Designing the Boss Encounter
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed the trigger for a boss fight, evolving from a simple concept to a multi-part narrative sequence. The final plan involves the player eavesdropping on Bowser, discovering the world state has changed, and then being ambushed, creating a more dramatic encounter.
key_stories.challenge: The level needed a compelling way to initiate its boss fight that was more interesting than simply walking into a portal.
key_stories.process: Kaze brainstormed ideas live, dismissing simpler triggers. He developed a narrative sequence where the player enters Bowser's office building, overhears Bowser ranting and sending a 'strike breaker', and then exits to find the protesting minions have vanished and the music has stopped. The boss then ambushes the player in the now-empty, silent plaza.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze designed a detailed, multi-step sequence that will guide the development of the level's climax. The plan uses environmental storytelling and builds tension before the fight begins.
key_stories.key_quote: As soon as you leave Bowser's tower, everyone is gone and the music has gone quiet... That's perfect.
